metadata.titleEn: The development of devices monitoring ecosystem energy and water flux: Mesoscale soil moisture measurement system (2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a mesoscale soil moisture measurement system of soil moisture of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, C), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Smart, real-time, low-cost, and distributed ecosystem monitoring is essential for understanding and managing rapidly changing ecosystems. However, new techniques in the big data era have rarely been introduced into operational ecosystem monitoring, particularly for fragile ecosystems in remote areas. Ecosystem monitoring can be defined as a time series of measurements of key variables in the biosphere and is designed to detect variability in ecosystem dynamics and ultimately answer questions regarding biospheric changes. Driven by the advancement of smart devices and rapid development of the Internet of Things (IoT), ecosystem monitoring has entered a new paradigm: monitoring the ecosystem based on the IoT. The advancement of embedded microprocessors and wireless communication has led to the development of smart devices for field-based and in situ environmental monitoring.
research objective: We introduce the Internet of Things (IoT) techniques to establish a prototype ecosystem monitoring system by developing innovative smart devices and using IoT technologies for ecosystem monitoring in isolated environments. The scientific objectives of this effort are as follows. (1) Develop innovative smart devices for monitoring key air, water, soil, and biota variables that have high measurement accuracy compared to that of conventional devices. The smart devices will be able to obtain network access via wireless communication modules. (2) Establish an ecosystem monitoring IoT that integrates automatic data acquisition and transmission, quality control, real-time data sharing, and online data visualization and analysis. (3) Test, verify and demonstrate the applicability of the ecosystem monitoring IoT in three typical fragile ecosystems for ecosystem monitoring and management.
challenges: The first challenge for achieving ecosystem monitoring via the IoT is to integrate heterogeneous WSNs into the Internet based on standard communication protocols, enabling smart devices to participate in the IoT. The second challenge is the efficient management of massive monitoring data sets. The third challenge is to design an effective ecosystem monitoring network that will provide the scientific information needed for ecosystem management and decision-making processes.
methods: The initiative includes three steps: developing the smart ecosystem monitoring devices, networking the devices and integrating them with the information system using the IoT, and testing the applicability of the ecosystem monitoring IoT in a variety of typical ecosystems across China.

Definition.Question: What is meant by '智能设备' in the context of ecosystem monitoring?
Definition.Answer: '智能设备' in the context of ecosystem monitoring refers to innovative smart devices developed for monitoring key environmental variables such as air, water, soil, and biota. These devices are characterized by their high measurement accuracy and capability to access networks via wireless communication modules, facilitating real-time data acquisition and sharing in isolated environments.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of data screening in the ecosystem water and heat parameter monitoring compare to the general practices of data screening in IoT-based ecosystem monitoring?
Comparison.Answer: The data screening method in the ecosystem water and heat parameter monitoring involves specific standards such as removing data based on voltage levels, relative humidity, sampling intervals, and changes in neutron counts. In contrast, IoT-based ecosystem monitoring focuses on integrating heterogeneous wireless sensor networks and managing massive datasets, which may involve different data screening practices tailored to the diversity and volume of data collected through IoT devices.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the challenge of data management in the ecosystem water and heat parameter monitoring differ from the challenges faced in IoT-based ecosystem monitoring networks?
Comparison.Answer: Data management in the ecosystem water and heat parameter monitoring involves specific data processing steps like pressure correction and instrument calibration, focusing on ensuring the accuracy of neutron counts and soil moisture data. On the other hand, IoT-based ecosystem monitoring networks face broader challenges in efficiently managing massive datasets, integrating heterogeneous networks, and designing monitoring networks that provide actionable scientific information for ecosystem management.

Interpretation.Question: How might integrating IoT techniques with smart devices enhance the accuracy and efficiency of ecosystem monitoring in remote and fragile environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating IoT techniques with smart devices enhances ecosystem monitoring by allowing for real-time data acquisition, automatic data transmission, and online data visualization, which improves measurement accuracy and system efficiency in isolated environments.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when attempting to manage and analyze massive datasets collected from heterogeneous wireless sensor networks (WSNs) in ecosystem monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include integrating heterogeneous WSNs using standard communication protocols for IoT participation and efficiently managing the massive datasets to provide necessary scientific information for ecosystem management and decision-making.

Interpretation.Question: What strategies could be employed to ensure that ecosystem monitoring devices maintain high measurement accuracy compared to conventional devices, especially for key variables in soil, air, and water?
Interpretation.Answer: Strategies include developing innovative smart devices with advanced embedded microprocessors and wireless communication capabilities, ensuring they are calibrated against known standards, and integrating them into an IoT system for real-time data quality control.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity of developing innovative smart devices for monitoring key variables in ecosystems, particularly in isolated environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for innovative smart devices arises from the requirement for high measurement accuracy in monitoring key air, water, soil, and biota variables, which are crucial for understanding ecosystem dynamics. Additionally, the advancement of smart devices, embedded microprocessors, and wireless communication technologies have enabled real-time, low-cost, and distributed ecosystem monitoring, which is essential for managing rapidly changing and fragile ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to manage massive datasets in ecosystem monitoring using IoT technologies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in managing massive datasets stems from the integration of heterogeneous wireless sensor networks (WSNs) into the Internet, which requires standard communication protocols. Efficient data management is critical for providing scientific information necessary for ecosystem management and decision-making processes, especially when dealing with large volumes of data collected from various smart devices.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating IoT techniques into ecosystem monitoring for fragile ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating IoT techniques into ecosystem monitoring can lead to the development of smart devices that offer high measurement accuracy and enable real-time data acquisition and transmission. This can enhance the ability to monitor and manage fragile ecosystems effectively by providing timely and accurate information for decision-making.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from addressing the challenges of managing massive monitoring datasets in ecosystem IoT networks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing the challenges of managing massive monitoring datasets in ecosystem IoT networks can lead to more efficient data processing and storage solutions, improved data quality control, and enhanced capabilities for real-time data sharing and analysis. This would allow for more comprehensive and effective ecosystem management and monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate automatic data acquisition and real-time data sharing in an ecosystem monitoring IoT?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating automatic data acquisition and real-time data sharing is crucial for efficiently managing massive monitoring datasets and ensuring the timely availability of high-quality data for ecosystem monitoring. This integration facilitates online data visualization and analysis, which is essential for understanding and managing rapidly changing ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of testing the applicability of an ecosystem monitoring IoT in various fragile ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include verifying the effectiveness and reliability of the IoT-based monitoring system in different ecosystems, demonstrating its applicability for ecosystem management, and providing valuable scientific information needed to address challenges in ecosystem monitoring and management.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in the data screening process to ensure the accuracy and reliability of soil moisture measurements in ecosystem monitoring?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data screening process involves several steps: removing data with voltage less than or equal to 11.8 volts, excluding data where relative humidity is greater than or equal to 80%, discarding data where the sampling interval is not within 60±1 minutes, and eliminating neutron count data that changes more than 200 between adjacent hours. Any excluded or missing data is supplemented with -6999.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is air pressure correction applied to neutron data in the context of soil moisture monitoring, and what is the significance of this step?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Air pressure correction is applied using a formula specified in the instrument's manual, which adjusts the raw neutron data to account for variations in air pressure. This correction is necessary to ensure that the neutron count reflects true soil moisture conditions, independent of atmospheric pressure changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the procedure for calibrating soil moisture measurement instruments using neutron count, and why is this calibration important for accurate data collection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Calibration involves determining the N0 value, which is the neutron count under dry soil conditions. This is done by measuring soil moisture in the area using soil samples or a dense network of soil moisture sensors, obtaining the corrected neutron data, and calculating N0 using a specific formula. Calibration is crucial to accurately convert neutron counts into soil moisture levels, reflecting true ground conditions.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in IoT technologies have enabled the development of smart ecosystem monitoring devices for remote and fragile environments?
Enablement.Answer: The advancements of embedded microprocessors and wireless communication have led to the development of smart devices for field-based and in situ environmental monitoring, enabling the integration of these devices into the Internet of Things (IoT) for ecosystem monitoring.

Enablement.Question: How do smart devices achieve high measurement accuracy for ecosystem monitoring compared to conventional devices?
Enablement.Answer: Smart devices are designed to monitor key air, water, soil, and biota variables with high measurement accuracy, and they obtain network access via wireless communication modules, which is a significant improvement over conventional devices.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be overcome to integrate heterogeneous wireless sensor networks into the Internet for ecosystem monitoring?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of heterogeneous wireless sensor networks into the Internet requires addressing challenges such as standardizing communication protocols and efficiently managing massive monitoring datasets to enable smart devices to participate in the IoT.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be difficulties in managing massive datasets collected from ecosystem monitoring IoT systems?
Expectation.Answer: Managing massive datasets from ecosystem monitoring IoT systems can be difficult due to the sheer volume of data generated by continuous and real-time monitoring. This requires efficient data management strategies to store, process, and analyze the data, ensuring data quality and accessibility while dealing with potential network bandwidth limitations.

Expectation.Question: Why might innovative smart devices developed for ecosystem monitoring need to have higher measurement accuracy compared to conventional devices?
Expectation.Answer: Innovative smart devices for ecosystem monitoring need higher measurement accuracy because they are designed to monitor key variables in fragile ecosystems, which require precise and reliable data to detect subtle changes and variations in ecosystem dynamics that are crucial for effective ecosystem management and decision-making.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential advantages and disadvantages of using IoT technologies for ecosystem monitoring in remote areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential advantages of using IoT technologies for ecosystem monitoring include the ability to obtain real-time data and high measurement accuracy, along with the integration of automatic data acquisition and transmission. The disadvantages might involve challenges such as integrating heterogeneous WSNs into the IoT, managing large datasets efficiently, and designing an effective monitoring network for scientific decision-making.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the development of smart devices improve the accuracy and reliability of monitoring key variables in ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Smart devices could improve the accuracy and reliability of monitoring by providing high measurement accuracy compared to conventional devices. They enable network access via wireless communication, allowing for real-time data sharing and online data visualization, which can enhance the precision and timeliness of ecosystem monitoring and management.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges faced when integrating heterogeneous wireless sensor networks (WSNs) with the Internet for ecosystem monitoring, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include integrating heterogeneous WSNs into the Internet using standard communication protocols and efficiently managing massive datasets. These challenges might be addressed by developing innovative smart devices, establishing an IoT ecosystem monitoring network, and employing rigorous quality control measures to ensure data integrity and usefulness for ecosystem management.

Assertion.Answer: Smart devices for ecosystem monitoring are developed to have high measurement accuracy and are integrated with wireless communication modules, enabling them to participate in IoT. These advancements allow for real-time data sharing, quality control, and online data visualization and analysis, which enhance the accuracy and efficiency of ecosystem monitoring.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when integrating ecosystem monitoring devices into the Internet of Things (IoT).
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges is integrating heterogeneous wireless sensor networks (WSNs) into the Internet using standard communication protocols to enable smart devices to participate in the IoT. Additionally, efficiently managing massive monitoring data sets and designing an effective monitoring network that provides necessary scientific information for ecosystem management are significant challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data from ecosystem monitoring devices are managed and utilized in real-time applications.
Assertion.Answer: The ecosystem monitoring IoT integrates automatic data acquisition and transmission with real-time data sharing, quality control, and online data visualization and analysis. This system facilitates the efficient management and utilization of data in real-time applications, enabling better ecosystem monitoring and management in isolated environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various data collection methods used for monitoring soil moisture in ecosystems, and describe how innovative smart devices can enhance measurement accuracy compared to conventional devices.
Request/Directive.Answer: Innovative smart devices can enhance soil moisture monitoring by utilizing IoT technologies for more precise and real-time data acquisition. These devices, equipped with advanced microprocessors and wireless communication modules, allow for more accurate measurements of soil moisture and integration into a comprehensive ecosystem monitoring IoT system.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a strategy for testing the applicability of an ecosystem monitoring IoT system in various fragile ecosystems, and outline the potential benefits for ecosystem management.
Request/Directive.Answer: Testing the applicability of an ecosystem monitoring IoT system involves deploying smart devices in diverse fragile ecosystems across China to collect and analyze key environmental variables. The benefits include improved data quality and accessibility, enabling informed decision-making and targeted ecosystem management strategies.
